title: 114_s385
content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports by the Congressional Budget Office and Committees, and completion of actions on the budget resolution by Congress. Biennial appropriation bills may be considered in the House by May 15. The House Appropriations Committee reports the last appropriation bill to be considered that year by June 10. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15. By June 30, the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will supersede the usual schedule. The schedule for budget-related actions includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports from the Congressional Budget Office, committee submissions, and Congress's completion of the budget resolution. Additionally, specific dates may vary in the first session of Congress following a leap year with a new President. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills, defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress follows the budget process to consider and enact appropriation bills. In even-numbered years, Congress considers and enacts annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year of the resolution for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium for defense. This involves adjustments to committee allocations and specifying the total of all fiscal years covered by the resolution. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves changing budget submissions to Congress by replacing references to specific fiscal years with each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves changing budget submissions to Congress by replacing references to specific fiscal years with each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four years. This includes adjustments to allowances for uncontrolled expenditures, tax expenditures, and future years. The amendment to Title 31, United States Code involves changing budget submissions to Congress by replacing references to specific fiscal years with each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four years. This includes adjustments to prior year outlays and receipts. The Title 31, United States Code is being amended to update budget submissions to Congress by referring to each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four years. This includes adjustments to prior year outlays and receipts, as well as estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches. Recommendations to address estimated deficiencies are also being revised. The Title 31, United States Code is being amended to update budget submissions by specifying each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four years. Recommendations to address estimated deficiencies are also being revised. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will have a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will be titled for the specific fiscal year. All Acts making regular appropriations must include specified amounts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the format and amounts of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will follow a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will be titled for the specific fiscal year. The table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1 is also amended accordingly. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include multiyear authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. It also restricts authorization or revenue bills until Congress completes action on the budget resolution and all appropriations bills. In the Senate, these restrictions do not apply to defense or privileged measures. In the Senate, subsection (a) exemptions include defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. The table of contents in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to reflect this. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings by House and Senate committees on agencies not funded under certain conditions. The hearings review agency missions, biennial budget impact, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study the impact of changing to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
